text: This is a download from BBC Learning English.
To find out more, visit our website.
6 Minute English
speaker: Neil

text: from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello, I'm Neil and welcome to 6 Minute English.
Where today we bring you a serious topic and six items of vocabulary.
And hello, I'm Rob.
Now, here's a serious question for you, Neil.
Have you thought about what you'd like to happen when you die?
Interesting way to start the show, Robâ€¦
speaker: Neil

text: No, I haven't.
Well, nobody really likes to talk about death, do they?
Well, it isn't a fun topic.
speaker: Neil

text: So can we talk about something else, please?
Afraid not, because today's topic is funerals.
A funeral is a ceremony we hold for a dead person.
And a ceremony is a formal event performed on special occasions
speaker: ceremony

text: like a wedding or a graduation, or in this case, a funeral.
Okay, well, let's start with a quiz question.
According to a UK survey,
how many of us would like our funerals to be more of a party or celebration?
speaker: Neil

text: Is it a 5%, b 25% or c 50%.
Well, I think it's 25%.
speaker: Rob

text: I hadn't thought about it before, but I definitely prefer my funeral to be a celebration
with my favourite music playing and definitely nobody wearing black.
Well, strangely enough, a friend of mine went to a funeral recently
speaker: Rob

text: where the funeral director was dressed as Darth Vader from Star Wars.
Hmm, that sounds wrong.
But I guess people are choosing to move away from the traditional funeral,
you know, in church, people dressed in black or very quiet.
Darth Vader does wear black, at least!
speaker: Rob

text: Anyway, let's hear from Shoney Sullivan here in the UK
talking about the fancy dress funeral she and her sister organised for their mother.
It was quite unusual as we turned up in fancy dress.
Had your mum left any instructions about how she wanted her funeral to be?
Only that we don't cry and we're to have a party,
just celebrate her life, be happy, don't be sad.
I was a witch.
speaker: Interviewer

text: How did you look
speaker: Interviewer

text: Oh, it was just like a little black dress and I just had like a little fancy
witch hat on at the same time as my sister and we had a very close friend of the family come
as Beetlejuice, which was absolutely amazing.
He really did go all out for that.
So fancy dress - special clothes you wear to an event
speaker: fancy dress costume

text: to look like a famous person or character from a movie.
speaker: Rob

text: Another word we use is costume, which is a set of clothes you wear to look like somebody else.
Shoney and her sister chose a Halloween theme for the funeral and what
witches costumes, little black dresses with special hats.
A close family relative dressed as Beetlejuice
speaker: Rob

text: Did he dress as a squashed in-sect Neil and I'm a bit confused here?
No, Rob. He dressed as Beetlejuice, the main character in a popular 1980s movie.
Beetlejuice is a ghost who wears crazy clothes and has scary hair and makeup.
I haven't seen the film, but what does Shoney mean when she says her relative went all out with his
costume?
speaker: Rob

text: To go all out means to make a big effort, and this guy's costume involved not only
special clothes, but special hair and makeup too.
Ah, like me. What do you mean like me?
Well, I go all out to get my clothes and hair just right for six minute English.
Yes, and well, you look great, Rob, but unfortunately nobody sees us do they?
speaker: Rob

text: Ah yes, good point. But it's important to make an effort.
So, have you had any thoughts about the sort of funeral you would like to have?
speaker: Rob

text: Oh, yes, I like the thought of my friends and family,
saying their final goodbyes to me on a beach with a beautiful sunset,
listening to Stay Away to Heaven by Led Zeppelin.
Okay, well, before you get too carried away with ideas for your own funeral,
let's have the answer to today's quiz question.
To get carried away means to get very excited and lose control of your feelings.
speaker: Neil

text: Hmm, I never thought I would get excited about my own funeral.
But anyway, yes, back to today's question,
how many of us would like our funerals to be more of a party or celebration?
Is it a 5%, b 25% or c 50%?
And I said 25%.
speaker: Neil

text: No, it's actually 50%.
The market research company ICN found that half of us here in the UK
would prefer something different to the traditional funeral.
More than I expected.
speaker: Neil

text: Okay, shall we look back at the words we have learned today?
Yep. First up, funeral.
A ceremony we hold for a dead person.
The plural is funerals.
Fancy dress funerals aren't everybody's cup of tea.
The adjective is funereal.
Notice the stress on the second syllable.
Who chose this funereal music?
Can we change it to something more cheerful?
'Not my cup of tea' by the way, is something you don't enjoy doing
speaker: Neil

text: Okay, ceremony, a formal event performed on special occasions.
I didn't go to my sister's graduation ceremony.
In the UK, the opening of Parliament is a ceremonious occasion.
Ceremonious is the adjective.
Number three, fancy dress is special clothing you wear to an event.
For example, to look like a famous person or character from a movie.
"I've been invited to a fancy dress party
speaker: Rob

text: Oh, who are you going as, Rob?
It's a secret, Neil!
speaker: Rob

text: Number four, costume.
A set of clothes you wear to look like somebody else.
Rob is going to go to the fancy dress party in a superman costume.
Ha, good guess.
Right, number five, to go all out means to make a big effort.
We went all out this year with our Christmas decorations,
with our life-size flashing Santa Claus and sleigh.
Now, way to go, Neil.
Number six, the phrasal verb to get carried away means to get very excited and lose control of your feelings.
"She got carried away and painted the whole house pink
speaker: Neil

text: That must be Barbie's house.
Yep.
And fancy dresses definitely Barbies cup of tea.
Okay, that's all for today,
but please remember to check out our Instagram, Twitter, Facebook and YouTube pages.
speaker: Neil

text: Okay, bye-bye.
Goodbye.
